stories.headline: Trump's tactics subvert vision of a 'Golden Age'
stories.summary: President Donald Trump faces challenges as he attempts to transform the U.S. economy into a self-reliant powerhouse, with his tactics often contrasted with previous presidents. His trade policies, especially those imposed since April, have brought uncertainty to global markets.

stories.headline: A rare N. Korean opening slams shut
stories.summary: In Hyesan, North Korea, once a bustling trade hub, recent measures have tightened restrictions dramatically. This move by Kim Jong Un's government has strained local businesses and disrupted daily life, reflecting a broader shift in policy.

stories.headline: Producer profits soar along with egg prices
stories.summary: The avian influenza outbreak has led to rising egg prices, impacting consumers and producers differently. Larger firms have profited substantially, while smaller producers face challenges. The USDA has intervened with payments to help mitigate some of the impacts.

stories.headline: High court halts order to rehire fired staff
stories.summary: The Supreme Court issued a ruling temporarily blocking an order for the Trump administration to rehire over 15,000 fired probationary employees. The decision provides a temporary victory for the administration, as litigation continues.

stories.headline: Stocks sink despite talk of trade deals
stories.summary: Despite discussions regarding potential trade deals, stock markets experienced a drop, with the S&P 500 nearing a bear market. Treasury Secretary Scott BesSent noted the complexity of the trade environment amidst ongoing international negotiations.

stories.headline: Columbia targeted by the right as a 'test case' in education war
stories.summary: Columbia University finds itself at the center of a cultural and educational debate. Criticism from conservative groups regarding diversity and educational policies positions Columbia as a pivotal example in broader discussions on higher education reform.

stories.headline: Leaders urge ‘call to action’ as domestic violence deaths soar
stories.summary: Kansas City leaders, including Mayor Quinton Lucas and Police Chief Stacey Graves, are calling for action in response to a spike in domestic violence-related homicides. In just over three months in 2025, Kansas City has already seen as many domestic violence-related deaths as in all of last year. Authorities are urging residents to report incidents and reassuring that support is available.

stories.headline: Sen. Moran backs bill to restrict Trump on tariffs
stories.summary: Senator Jerry Moran, a Kansas Republican, supports a bipartisan bill that would limit President Donald Trump's ability to impose tariffs without Congressional approval. The bill requires the President to notify Congress before imposing new tariffs, and Congress would have 60 days to approve them. Moran's support aligns with concerns from Kansas farmers and other constituents about the negative impacts of tariffs on various industries.

stories.headline: Prairiefire project adds 90-room hotel, retail space
stories.summary: The Prairiefire development in Overland Park is undergoing another expansion with the addition of a 90-room hotel and additional retail space. After receiving approval from the Planning Commission, the project aims to enhance the existing retail and dining offerings despite previous struggles and controversies. The development is expected to include significant retail space and residential units, aiming to draw more visitors to the area.

stories.headline: Could tariffs lead to the dreaded R word — recession?
stories.summary: The article discusses the potential economic impact of a 10% blanket duty on nearly all countries, taking effect today. President Trump's tariff hikes have provoked fears of a recession, with Wall Street and economists expressing concerns over potential economic downturns if tariffs persist. Various economists offer different forecasts, with the Federal Reserve monitoring the situation closely.

stories.headline: Republican congressman announces bid for governor
stories.summary: U.S. Rep. John James announced his candidacy for governor in Michigan, making him the second major GOP candidate in the race. His campaign focuses on promoting unity and family values, with a nod to former President Trump's policies. James aims to strengthen the state's economy and community ties.

stories.headline: Democrats renew effort to allow bans on plastic shopping bags
stories.summary: Democrats in the Michigan Senate and House reintroduced bills that aim to grant local governments the authority to ban or tax plastic shopping bags. They argue this will restore local control and address environmental concerns related to litter and waste. The legislative push indicates a renewed environmental focus in state politics.

stories.headline: These coffee nerds are no ordinary joes
stories.summary: A team at the University of Pennsylvania is exploring new methods to make coffee tastier using fewer beans. This research comes at a time when coffee prices are rising due to reduced production and increased demand.

stories.headline: They see an erosion in Lady Liberty’s promise
stories.summary: Changes in U.S. policies under President Donald Trump’s administration have led to shifting perceptions of America abroad. Criticisms from figures like Raphael Glucksmann highlight concerns over the U.S.’s new direction and its global image.

stories.headline: Justices halt reinstatement of fired federal employees
stories.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court temporarily blocked a lower court's injunction that would have reinstated thousands of federal employees fired by the Trump administration. This decision leaves many in limbo as legal questions remain about the dismissals.

stories.headline: Trump team sees hope in trade war
stories.summary: The global trade war led by President Donald Trump escalated as China vowed to retaliate against tariffs. Despite threats from China, the Trump administration remains firm on its trade policies, suggesting potential leverage in negotiations.

stories.headline: Detained U student may testify
stories.summary: A University of Minnesota student facing legal issues since August may have a chance to testify. The student's arrest has drawn attention due to an ongoing federal immigration case. Proceedings are set to continue as his case returns to court.

stories.headline: Scientists say they've 'brought back' dire wolves. Not exactly.
stories.summary: Scientists from a biotech firm claim to have introduced a species genetically resembling the extinct dire wolf. However, they clarify that it's not identical, as the new species is a hybrid using modern animals' DNA. The announcement sparks both excitement and skepticism in the scientific community.

stories.headline: Complaints continue about Postal Service in south metro cities
stories.summary: Residents in several cities in Minnesota continue to face issues with postal delays, raising concerns about mail delivery service reliability. Many residents report not receiving their mail regularly, leading to frustration with the postal system.

stories.headline: Despite pleas, Trump digs in on his tariffs
stories.summary: President Trump announced his intention to make tariffs on certain imports permanent, despite requests from leaders for a delay. The decision is meant to address trade imbalances, but the announcement has prompted foreign leaders to consider trade retaliation. The tariffs include a significant rate increase for China.

stories.headline: Layoffs slow FDA device approvals
stories.summary: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration is experiencing a significant slowdown in medical device approvals, reportedly reaching a ten-year low. This is attributed to recent layoffs and a rise in pending applications. Companies are uncertain about the regulatory impacts and their financial projections are affected. Affected professionals express frustration over employment issues.

stories.headline: China Tells Trump it Will Fight ‘Blackmail’
stories.summary: Tensions rise as China responds to President Trump's threat of increased tariffs on Chinese goods. China vows to retaliate against what it calls 'blackmail,' with Chinese officials and U.S. politicians weighing in on the escalating trade conflict.

stories.headline: Police Find More Info on Deadly House Fire
stories.summary: A fatal house fire in West Bloomfield, Michigan, led to the discovery of children's deaths after they couldn't escape due to locked doors, a safety measure taken for an autistic child. The article discusses ongoing police investigations and safety concerns raised by the incident.

stories.headline: Forward Progress
stories.summary: Siena Heights University adds a college flag football team, with receiver Kyamora Dunn making history as part of the inaugural team. The article highlights the growing popularity of flag football at the college level, showcasing Siena Heights' successful debut against Villa Maria College.

stories.headline: Today's Almanac
stories.summary: Today's Almanac provides historical context for April 9, highlighting significant events such as the surrender of General Lee at Appomattox Court House and other notable occurrences on this day in history.

stories.headline: Turf Battle: State lawmakers consider a three-year moratorium on artificial turf playing fields in Maine
stories.summary: State lawmakers in Maine are debating a potential three-year moratorium on the installation of artificial turf playing fields. This proposal is driven by environmental concerns and health implications related to the materials used in these fields.

stories.headline: Police identify snowboarder who died at Sugarloaf last weekend
stories.summary: Authorities have identified the snowboarder who tragically died at Sugarloaf last weekend. This incident has brought attention to safety measures at the popular ski resort and raised concerns among local communities.

stories.headline: Mainers could see higher taxes if US cuts local bond exemptions
stories.summary: Congress is considering changes to municipal bonds that could increase tax burdens for towns and cities in Maine. These bonds play a crucial role in funding public projects, and if federal exemptions are removed, local officials warn of higher costs for taxpayers.

stories.headline: Pingree to hold town halls as more voters demand to meet lawmakers in person
stories.summary: Representative Chellie Pingree has announced in-person town hall events to connect more directly with her constituents. In response to demands for greater accountability, these events offer voters a chance to engage on key issues such as climate change and federal spending.

stories.headline: At the Portland Museum of Art, florists offer a fresh perspective
stories.summary: The Portland Museum of Art is hosting the Art in Bloom event, where florists create installations inspired by art pieces. This event offers a unique perspective by merging floral design with artworks from various artists, attracting up to 10,000 visitors.

stories.headline: Maine prisons to lose some funds over transgender inmate, AG says
stories.summary: The U.S. attorney general announced that some funding to Maine prisons is being withheld due to the state's handling of a transgender inmate. This decision came after Maine reportedly failed to comply with President Trump's directive concerning transgender rights. The Department of Justice is freezing funds meant for substance use treatment and other support due to this issue.

stories.headline: Supreme Court halts order to rehire probationary workers
stories.summary: The Supreme Court has temporarily blocked the Trump administration's mandate to rehire over 16,000 fired probationary employees. The decision was based on procedural grounds, asserting that the legal authority cited did not apply to mass rehiring attempts. It marks a legal setback to the administration’s efforts to reverse decisions made for fiscal reasons.

stories.headline: Amazon effort to challenge Starlink is on the launchpad
stories.summary: Amazon's satellite internet venture, Project Kuiper, is set to compete with SpaceX’s Starlink. The project aims to improve global broadband access through a planned launch of 3,200 satellites. This effort signifies a landmark as Amazon seeks to broaden its capabilities in internet connectivity and customer outreach.

stories.headline: 15 college students, recent graduates in Washington have had visas revoked
stories.summary: Fifteen students and recent graduates in Washington have had their visas canceled by the Trump administration due to a status check by the federal government. The university stated that affected students faced various challenges, including abruptly terminating studies and decisions to leave the country. Legal support is being provided to those impacted.

stories.headline: Microsoft retakes spot as richest company in the world
stories.summary: Microsoft has overtaken Apple as the world's most valuable company due to market shifts influenced by political factors such as tariff announcements. In response to this, the company's stock has seen a significant increase, surpassing Apple's market cap temporarily despite recent financial uncertainties caused by tariff concerns.

stories.headline: School superintendent pushes back against Trump’s DEI order
stories.summary: Washington's state school superintendent will not comply with the Trump administration’s diversity, equity, and inclusion order for public schools, citing a lack of federal requirements. The U.S. Department of Education had warned it would withhold funding if compliance wasn't observed within 10 days. State Superintendent Chris Reykdal questioned the legality, stating that the state would follow longstanding regulations.

stories.headline: Navy SEAL. Doctor. Astronaut. The Guy You Hope Mom Doesn’t Meet.
stories.summary: Jonny Kim's impressive accomplishments as a Navy SEAL, doctor, and astronaut make him a role model for many, inspiring through his diverse achievements and dedication.

stories.headline: Homeowners Amassed $35 Trillion In Housing Wealth—But at a Cost
stories.summary: The booming housing market has increased American homeowners' wealth, but also raised expenses and created economic disparities, as access to homeownership remains a challenge for many.

stories.headline: Rudderless Leadership, Divisions Hamstring Palestinians
stories.summary: The Palestinian authority faces internal divisions, weakening the political and social structure necessary for effective governance amidst ongoing Israeli-Palestinian tensions.

stories.headline: Broad U.S. Tariffs Take Effect As China Vows ‘Fight to the End’
stories.summary: President Trump imposed tariffs on Chinese imports, escalating economic tensions. China promises to respond in kind, leading to a potential trade war between the two nations.

stories.headline: Massive Selloff Batters Buyers on Dip
stories.summary: The S&P 500 closes below 5000 for the first time in nearly a year as early rally fizzles. Investors suffered losses as stocks fell sharply after an initial surge, signaling market instability.

stories.headline: Scientists Aim to Mirror Long-Extinct Wolf
stories.summary: U.S. scientists have created genetically engineered wolves that may resemble the long-extinct dire wolves. This breakthrough in genetic engineering opens questions about conservation and ethical implications.

stories.headline: His final bow: Band director likes sharing love of music
stories.summary: Clay Sloan, the Austin High School band director, announced he will retire after this school year. Sloan, who has been at the school for over two decades, has influenced many students. He began his career in 1983 and has been deeply passionate about music education.

stories.headline: Legal fight over deportations not over after ruling
stories.summary: The Supreme Court ruled that immigrants can be detained indefinitely without a court hearing while challenging deportation. The decision affects many immigrants and has prompted political and legal debates on the issue.

stories.headline: White House keeps world guessing on tariffs
stories.summary: Journalists were unable to get clear information from President Trump regarding upcoming tariff changes. Investors and world leaders remain anxious about potential disruptions to the global economy as tariff negotiations continue.

stories.headline: 2 selected for interviews
stories.summary: The search for a new Decatur police chief has narrowed to two candidates, Tony Mack and Theophilus Smith. Human Resources Director Richelle Sandlin announced the selection after reviewing applications. Interviews are scheduled for April 15 or 16.

stories.headline: Supreme Court Halts Order to Rehire Worker
stories.summary: The Supreme Court issued an order stopping the rehiring of over 16,000 fired Postal Service and other federal employees. This order was initially granted by a lower court concerning improper personnel practices during mass dismissals by the Trump administration.

stories.headline: Panel Backs Heinz History Center Expansion
stories.summary: The Pittsburgh Planning Commission approved the expansion of the Heinz History Center. Plans include demolishing several nearby buildings to create space for a new orientation theater and exhibition space. This move is seen as a positive step for local cultural developments.

stories.headline: Asian Grocery Stores Already Feeling Impact of Tariffs
stories.summary: Asian grocery stores, primarily importing goods from Asia, are seeing increased costs due to the looming tariffs announced by the Trump administration. This has resulted in higher prices for customers and concerns about future supply disruptions.

stories.headline: Mixed Messages: White House Keeps World Guessing on Tariffs
stories.summary: Journalists sought clarity on President Donald Trump’s trade tariffs, but the administration remained vague about which tariffs would take effect. The uncertainty left businesses worldwide anxious, especially with potential global economic impacts.

stories.headline: CMU Student Visas Revoked
stories.summary: The Trump administration has revoked the international student visas of two current Carnegie Mellon University students and fewer recent graduates. The university was informed through a Department of Homeland Security letter, which did not specify the reasons for revocation. This has raised concerns within the community.

stories.headline: ‘Unprecedented.’ IRS plans to give tax data of migrants to ICE
stories.summary: The IRS agrees to provide tax information of migrants to the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency, a move considered unprecedented and raising privacy concerns. This collaboration aims to enhance enforcement capabilities but faces criticism regarding the breach of taxpayer confidentiality.

stories.headline: Is Miami-Dade’s Jewish population growing? A major new survey has the answer
stories.summary: A decade-long survey by the Greater Miami Jewish Federation reveals a 25% increase in the Jewish population in Miami-Dade County over the past decade, driven largely by younger newcomers. This comprehensive survey provides insights into the demographic and cultural shifts within the community.

stories.headline: State officials steered $10 million settlement to Casey DeSantis’ Hope Florida charity
stories.summary: A $10 million settlement intended for a state trust was directed towards Hope Florida, a charity linked to Casey DeSantis. This movement of funds is seen as potentially influencing Casey DeSantis’ future political campaigns. The decision has sparked discussions regarding the transparency and intentions behind such allocations.

stories.headline: Man detained in Miami: Send me to Spain instead of keeping me in detention
stories.summary: Eduardo Nuñez Gonzalez, a Cuban national, is detained by immigration officials and seeks to be sent to Spain rather than remain in detention. The article highlights the personal and legal struggles faced by Gonzalez and his wife, Vilma Perez Delgado, amid U.S. immigration policies.

stories.headline: Election Day in Coral Gables
stories.summary: Candidates Felix Pardo, Kirk Menendez, Michael Abbott, and Tom Wells are pictured campaigning outside of the Coral Gables Country Club on the eve of the election. Meanwhile, Coral Gables Mayor Vince Lago engages with residents at a local library. The focus is on the competitive race for commissioner positions and mayor.

stories.headline: DJ Daniel, 13, honored by Texas House during his cancer battle
stories.summary: DJ Daniel, a 13-year-old battling cancer, was honored by the Texas House for his resilience and courage. Recognized for his positive spirit, Daniel's story has inspired many, highlighting the support from the community and Texas lawmakers during his battle with the disease.

stories.headline: DA Garza resolves suit over records
stories.summary: Travis County District Attorney José Garza has settled a lawsuit regarding the use of taxpayer money for securing his home. The settlement comes after accusations of improperly using public funds, detailing payments for security enhancements. The end of the lawsuit involved a public statement and an agreement to release related documents.

stories.headline: Migrants may face fines under Trump orders
stories.summary: The Trump administration plans to fine undocumented immigrants up to $999 a day for failing to comply with deportation orders. This move is seen as an effort to instill fear in immigrant communities. The plan has drawn criticism from immigration advocates and legal experts.

stories.headline: China accuses Trump of 'blackmail'
stories.summary: President Donald Trump’s tariff threats have intensified tensions with China, which accused him of 'blackmail'. China has vowed to impose its own tariffs on US goods if the situation escalates. The standoff is part of a global trade conflict involving tariff hikes and potential economic repercussions.

stories.headline: Mütter Museum’s Embattled Director Ousted
stories.summary: Kate Quinn, the embattled director of the Mütter Museum, has been ousted. Her leadership faced criticism, although some changes were seen as positive. The future leadership of the museum is under consideration.

stories.headline: Supreme Court Lifts Order That Demanded Rehiring
stories.summary: The Supreme Court lifted an order that required businesses to rehire workers, impacting over 16,000 employees. This decision underscores the complex legal landscape regarding employment policies.

stories.headline: Markets Reflect Ongoing Tariffs Turmoil
stories.summary: Markets are experiencing turmoil due to ongoing tariffs, as President Trump signals willingness to negotiate with global leaders. This uncertainty affects businesses and global trade.

stories.headline: $264M in Project Funding for Pa. Lost in Congress’ Budget Battle
stories.summary: Pennsylvania has lost $264 million in project funding due to Congress excluding earmarks in the budget. This affects various local projects and has sparked debate among state officials.

stories.headline: Who Destroyed the Yarn Bomb Display at Passyunk Square?
stories.summary: A colorful yarn bomb display in Passyunk Square has been destroyed, sparking curiosity and disappointment among residents. The community is seeking answers and considering restoring the artwork.

stories.headline: Carnaval de Puebla Canceled Amid Fears Over Ice
stories.summary: The annual Carnaval de Puebla has been canceled due to concerns about icy conditions. Organizers made the decision to prioritize safety, impacting local cultural celebrations.

stories.headline: Built to Lose, Sixers 'Understand What the Assignment Is'
stories.summary: The Philadelphia 76ers are focusing on the process of building their team despite losing games. The organization is optimistic about their future prospects and player development.

stories.headline: Democrats target Kentucky's 6th Congressional District
stories.summary: Democrats are focusing efforts on Kentucky's 6th Congressional District for the 2026 election cycle, citing changing political dynamics and local dissatisfaction with Republican policies. The Democratic Campaign Committee lists this district as one of their priorities, marking a significant political move in the state.

stories.headline: Communication mix-up over Dix Dam release video causes uproar
stories.summary: A video mistakenly suggesting a water release from Dix Dam created panic among residents along the Kentucky River. The video was posted by a local emergency manager, misinforming the public and causing an uproar. Authorities later clarified that no release had taken place, underscoring the confusion and need for accurate communication in emergencies.

stories.headline: Kentucky's flooded rivers reach historic crests
stories.summary: Several days of heavy rainfall have caused the Kentucky River and other waterways to overflow, leading to extensive flooding across the region. Five people, including a 9-year-old boy, have died as a result of the floods. The situation highlights ongoing concerns about flood management and emergency response in the area.

stories.headline: Trump seeks to spend $45B to expand immigrant detention
stories.summary: The Trump administration plans to spend tens of billions of dollars to expand immigrant detention on an unprecedented scale in the United States. This proposal seeks $45 billion over the next five years for detention facilities and services, despite concerns over available funding. This initiative marks a significant policy move by the Trump administration in its immigration agenda.

stories.headline: Tariffs sending tremors through auto industry
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's 25% tariffs on imported vehicles have sparked significant uncertainty within the auto industry. Companies like Land Rover are pausing imports, leading to potential job losses and economic challenges within Michigan and other states.

stories.headline: NBA referee Crawford named to Hall of Fame
stories.summary: Danny Crawford, a long-time Naperville resident, is inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame after an illustrious 32-year career as an NBA referee. Crawford reflects on his career and expresses honor and surprise at receiving the recognition.

stories.headline: Election board: Harmon improperly took $4M
stories.summary: Illinois Senate President Don Harmon is accused of accepting $4 million more in political contributions than allowed, according to the State Board of Elections. An investigation is underway to resolve the issue, with Harmon given until April 18 to address the campaign contribution limits.

stories.headline: Progress hazy for diversity in CPD
stories.summary: Mayor Brandon Johnson discusses the challenges and ongoing efforts to increase diversity within the Chicago Police Department. Despite declaring an intention to diversify the force, recent statistics reveal slow progress in incorporating minorities into the police force.

stories.headline: Moore Signs Workforce Bills, Acknowledges Trump Impact on State
stories.summary: Maryland Governor Wes Moore has signed workforce bills aimed at improving the state's labor market. During the signing, he acknowledged the impact of federal policies under President Trump, noting challenges but also expressing a commitment to positive change.

stories.headline: 'Horrible' Autopsy Images Shown
stories.summary: During a murder trial for a high-profile case, graphic autopsy images were displayed, causing distress. A detective emphasized the seriousness of the crime while explaining the gruesome details gathered from the investigation.

stories.headline: Some Student Visas Revoked at Hopkins, UMBC and UMD
stories.summary: Certain students from major Maryland universities have had their visas revoked as part of a national security investigation. These students are required to leave the U.S., creating tension and uncertainty within the affected educational institutions.

stories.headline: 'Extremely Concerned' About Budget
stories.summary: Baltimore City Council President Zeke Cohen expressed deep concern about the fines and fees included in Mayor Brandon Scott's proposed budget. The potential negative impact on local communities is worrisome, with Cohen calling it a move that comes at a wrong time for the city.

stories.headline: Some Md. Businesses Say Tariffs Cause 'Confusion'
stories.summary: Maryland businesses are expressing concern over recent tariffs announced by President Donald Trump. These policies have created confusion and worry among business owners about potential cost increases and economic impact.

stories.headline: Supreme Court Blocks Order to Reinstate Workers
stories.summary: The Supreme Court has blocked an order aimed at reinstating thousands of federal workers put on leave following a mass firing. The decision goes against an earlier ruling by a federal judge in California. The move was in response to ongoing disputes around orders made under President Trump's administration.

stories.headline: Manufacturing losses loom over Whitmer's pitch
stories.summary: Michigan faces challenges in maintaining its manufacturing jobs as Governor Gretchen Whitmer prepares to propose new initiatives in Washington, D.C. Despite losing jobs, Whitmer aims to make a case for revitalizing the state's manufacturing sector to protect economic interests.

stories.headline: PFAS rules risk harbor dredging in Michigan
stories.summary: New environmental regulations from Michigan authorities regarding PFAS testing in harbors could significantly increase shipping costs and affect port operations. Critics argue the mandates are a logistical challenge, while supporters see it as necessary for environmental safety.

stories.headline: 'My world has just been turned upside down'
stories.summary: Authorities have identified the body of Ayva Sutton, a 9-year-old girl from Detroit, as one of three found in a burnt-out car. Her mother, Elaurenta Sutton, and family are grieving the devastating loss. Detroit police continue their investigation into the tragic incident.

stories.headline: World braces for new tariffs
stories.summary: Amid global uncertainty, President Donald Trump has expressed the desire to make 'highly tailored' deals with countries over tariffs. As stocks drop and businesses prepare for potential impacts, the White House is signaling a readiness to negotiate trade terms to alleviate concerns.

stories.headline: Voucher plan could help Muslim, Jewish schools
stories.summary: A new state bill proposes educational vouchers that would benefit not only Christian private schools but also Muslim and Jewish institutions. While most legislation discussions have been Christian-focused, proponents highlight the wider range of potential beneficiaries.

stories.headline: A major shift in teacher pay at HISD
stories.summary: Houston ISD will link teacher compensation to performance rather than experience starting in the 2026-27 school year. This change aims to more effectively reward highly effective teachers by basing salaries on performance ratings rather than years of service or educational background.

stories.headline: Utility's plan lacks refunds for unused generators
stories.summary: Texas lawmakers criticized CenterPoint Energy for not refunding customers for unused generators after the company collected controversial fees following previous power shortages. Instead, state officials commend a proposal to leverage these fees for future infrastructure improvements.

stories.headline: Texas Lotto jackpot winner's suit says rigged game cut payout
stories.summary: Jerry Reed, a Texas Lotto winner, claims the state lottery used misleading practices that reduced his jackpot payout. His lawsuit raises concerns about the lottery's integrity, particularly regarding an annuity-based payout, which Reed alleges to be less than initially promised.

stories.headline: Tariffs trigger budget worries
stories.summary: Senator Lincoln Hough expressed concerns about the impact of Trump's tariffs, which he believes could cause economic instability, particularly in the stock market. This sentiment was echoed by other members of the Missouri Senate who are focusing on the implications for budget planning, given the unpredictable nature of the tariffs' effects.

stories.headline: Flooding far less than was predicted
stories.summary: Recent flooding in areas like Eureka and Valley Park along the Meramec River turned out to be less severe than weather forecasts had predicted. Although they prepared for higher flood levels, officials found only minor issues, resulting in relief for residents who had feared the worst. Some roads saw water, but significant problems were avoided.

stories.headline: Making It Count: Municipal Election
stories.summary: Local elections in St. Louis saw voters turning out to cast their votes, reflecting the importance of civic participation. The elections, held on April 8, were part of the municipal election cycle aiming to boost local governance. Engaging visuals show voters, including families, making their voice count at polling stations.

stories.headline: Bill pits police against lobbyist
stories.summary: A new gun-rights measure in Missouri has sparked controversy by putting police chiefs against a firearms activist known for aggressive lobbying tactics. The measure, an updated version of a previously struck-down bill, places Republicans in a politically awkward position between gun-rights activists and the police. The bill, supported by Aaron Dorr of the Missouri Firearms Coalition, mandates changes that some police chiefs are opposing.

stories.headline: US markets decline again
stories.summary: The US stock market experienced another decline amid uncertainties caused by President Trump's tariff policies. The market volatility was highlighted by a drop in major indexes, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, as investors responded to ongoing trade fears and potential price hikes.

stories.headline: Anti-DEI bill scaled back in committee
stories.summary: Indiana House lawmakers have significantly pared back a controversial anti-DEI bill, citing it as a step in the right direction. This decision may ease some concerns yet still faces criticism from various groups.

stories.headline: Living high downtown
stories.summary: Historic offices in Indianapolis are being converted into luxury apartments. These conversions aim to revitalize and modernize the downtown area, contributing to a growing trend of adaptive reuse projects.

stories.headline: 2nd-half performance boosts Haliburton’s case for All-NBA
stories.summary: An impressive second-half performance by an Indy basketball player has strengthened his case for being named to the All-NBA team. The focus is on the player’s achievements and the impact on his team.

stories.headline: Indiana reports first measles case of '25
stories.summary: The Indiana Department of Health has announced the state's first laboratory-confirmed case of measles in 2025. Health officials are investigating potential exposures and providing updates on the patient's recovery.

stories.headline: Order to reinstate thousands of federal workers blocked
stories.summary: The Supreme Court blocked a Trump administration order to reinstate thousands of federal workers who had been let go. This is the third Supreme Court decision against the administration, maintaining a ruling that the layoffs were improperly executed and possibly politically motivated.

stories.headline: Florida’s Cubans, once a protected class, face new immigration threats
stories.summary: Cubans in Florida, previously given a more straightforward path to residency under policies from the Cold War era, now face new immigration challenges under shifting policies. The change in policies has made it more difficult for Cuban immigrants to secure their status in the U.S., affecting their sense of security.

stories.headline: How is Tampa Bay recovering?
stories.summary: Six months after hurricanes Helene and Milton, Tampa Bay is still grappling with recovery. Many homes are being inspected, permits are still being filed, and some residents remain displaced. The article explores ongoing challenges and efforts to rebuild, highlighting the efforts of local agencies and the community.

stories.headline: Fla. car insurance could soar because of tariffs
stories.summary: Florida car owners may face a significant increase in car insurance premiums due to potential tariffs. Current rates are already high, and experts suggest that President Donald Trump’s tariffs on materials like steel and aluminum could worsen the situation. Without tariffs, premiums would average around $3,500 annually, but with tariffs, they could rise significantly.

stories.headline: Pentagon launches ‘crazy’ race to build quantum computer
stories.summary: The Pentagon has initiated a 'crazy' contest to develop a useful quantum computer amidst skepticism and futuristic promise. The goal is to create machines capable of solving complex problems efficiently, but the undertaking faces massive challenges.

stories.headline: Justices back Trump, freeze order to rehire federal bureaucrats
stories.summary: The Supreme Court supported President Trump by freezing an order that compelled the rehiring of federal workers who were laid off. This decision has significant implications for employment practices within the federal government, marking a major administration victory.

stories.headline: Startups form glow bunnies, dire wolves
stories.summary: A new class of startups is using genetic modification to reshape the animal kingdom. Their scientific team managed to turn biological processes into programmable ones by using modifications, including creating glow bunnies and dire wolves, to reshape the animal landscape.

stories.headline: No exemptions, no apologies, no delays for tariffs
stories.summary: President Trump will not pause or postpone hefty tariffs that target dozens of countries or massive new levies on China that were to take effect at midnight Tuesday. The administration has sent shock waves through global markets and allied nations with a worldwide tariff blitz.

stories.headline: Supreme Court rules Trump can resume deportations using Alien Enemies Act
stories.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court has vacated a temporary restraint that prevented enforcement of deportation orders under the Alien Enemies Act. This decision involves detaining and removing migrants from countries the U.S. considers hostile. The ruling has sparked criticism from legal and civil rights groups.

stories.headline: Leno, Grove cruise Capitol for classic car smog exemption
stories.summary: Comedian Jay Leno and State Sen. Shannon Grove are rallying support for a bill that would exempt classic cars older than 35 years from California's smog regulations. The proposed law, dubbed 'Leno’s Law', seeks bipartisan support in the California Senate. Leno emphasized the culture and heritage of classic car enthusiasts as a reason to pass the bill.

stories.headline: Inside California's fight against Trump's citizenship order
stories.summary: California officials are preparing to contest President Trump's executive order that seeks to deny citizenship to children of undocumented immigrants. San Francisco City Attorney David Chiu and California Attorney General Rob Bonta are coordinating efforts to challenge the order, potentially leading to a long legal battle.

stories.headline: Global leaders rush to woo Trump, hoping to sway him on tariffs
stories.summary: As President Trump's proposed tariffs loom, governments around the world are reaching out to the U.S. to negotiate terms. European officials have offered to drop duties on some industrial goods, and leaders in Vietnam and Indonesia are willing to meet directly with the U.S. government. Trump's administration has sent mixed signals about willingness to negotiate, but the tariffs are set to take effect soon.

stories.headline: A mystery resurfaces off coast: Rising gray whale deaths
stories.summary: Scientists are investigating a troubling increase in gray whale deaths along the North American Pacific Coast. This spike, mirroring a similar die-off six years ago, has raised concerns about the underlying causes and the overall health of the marine environment in these areas.

stories.headline: Tariffs put L.A. toy and apparel makers in a bind
stories.summary: L.A.'s toy and apparel industries are facing increased pressure as new tariffs make production costly and complex. Many goods that were produced in China are now subject to tariffs, forcing companies to explore alternative manufacturing options. This has led to concerns about the viability and future of these sectors.

stories.headline: Social Security service upended by cuts
stories.summary: Budget cuts have led to significant delays and reductions in services at Social Security offices nationwide. Many are now struggling to access crucial resources, with vulnerable populations bearing the brunt of the changes. This has sparked widespread concern and calls for attention to the issue.

stories.headline: Canadian snowbirds, stung by Trump, flock from Palm Springs
stories.summary: Canadian visitors, who have traditionally flocked to Palm Springs for the winter, are now leaving due to dissatisfaction with President Trump's policies. This trend could harm the local economy as Canadians decide to vacation elsewhere, potentially affecting local businesses reliant on these tourists.

stories.headline: Retaliation foreshadows challenges of trade war
stories.summary: Canada and China plan to impose tariffs on select U.S. exports beginning Wednesday, sparking concerns over a potential trade war. The move comes in response to actions from the Trump administration, aiming to pressure the U.S. back to the negotiating table. Speculation arises as markets react negatively to the news, with implications for global economic relations.

stories.headline: Officials concerned about ICE arrests at courthouse
stories.summary: Tensions rise as ICE conducts arrests at the Milwaukee County Courthouse. Local officials and advocates express concerns over the implications for immigrants, citing potential threats to the principles of judicial processes and community trust.

stories.headline: Lakeshore State Park burn will boost plant diversity
stories.summary: Lakeshore State Park conducted a controlled burn to eliminate invasive species and encourage native flora growth. The prescribed burn aims to restore the urban prairie environment on Lake Michigan's shores. Officials from the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources emphasized the importance of preserving native biodiversity.

stories.headline: Promising start to '25 crime statistics
stories.summary: Milwaukee shows a decrease in crime statistics with notable drops in property theft and aggravated assaults, though homicides have slightly increased. Remarks from Mayor Cavalier Johnson highlight aspirations for crime reductions while Police Chief Jeffrey Norman addresses reasons behind the homicide statistics.

stories.headline: Some Hit Back, Most Bend
stories.summary: Several countries, including China and Canada, are retaliating against Trump's tariffs with their own measures, leading to increased tensions and trade disruptions worldwide.

stories.headline: Revivifying an Extinct Wolf Breed That Dominated the Stone Age
stories.summary: Scientists have successfully edited the genome of an extinct wolf species, bringing it back to life. This breakthrough offers exciting possibilities for de-extinction science and biodiversity restoration.

stories.headline: I.R.S. Will Give Migrants' Data to ICE Officials
stories.summary: In a controversial decision, the IRS will provide migrant information to ICE. This move aids immigration enforcement but raises privacy concerns among civil rights groups.

stories.headline: A Captive for Decades Finds Freedom in a Fire
stories.summary: A man who had been held captive since childhood was freed after a fire broke out at his residence. His ordeal lasted years, with authorities unaware of his confinement until the emergency incident occurred.

stories.headline: Justices Duck a Showdown
stories.summary: The Supreme Court is avoiding new rulings that would directly confront President Trump's authority in certain areas. Critics suggest this is a strategic move to maintain the court’s legitimacy in a politically charged era.

stories.headline: Aftermath of Deluge That Lasted Days
stories.summary: A deluge in Frankfort, Kentucky, caused the Kentucky River to burst its banks, resulting in significant flooding. Emergency workers were dispatched to check power lines and assess the damage in the affected areas.

stories.headline: Brushing Off Concerns, Trump Pushes Forward With His Steep Tariffs
stories.summary: President Trump has decided to proceed with his 25% tariffs on imported vehicles, despite warnings from automakers and international partners. The tariffs were intended to protect domestic industry, but have led to tensions with key US trading partners.

stories.headline: Deportation flights planned
stories.summary: Avelo Airlines is set to begin operating deportation-related flights from Phoenix-Mesa Gateway Airport as part of the Trump administration's mass deportations strategy. These flights represent a continued effort in immigration enforcement, marking a notable development in Arizona's role in these federal initiatives.

stories.headline: Big Tobacco lied, sellers say
stories.summary: Arizona sellers of electronic cigarettes claim representatives of a Big Tobacco company misled them regarding support for legislation on flavored vape products. The sellers accuse the company of dishonesty about backing a bill that would ban flavored vapes, raising tensions within the industry over regulatory impacts.

stories.headline: Border czar calls for more money, resources
stories.summary: U.S. border czar Tom Homan emphasizes the need for increased funding and resources at the southern border, particularly in light of recent enforcement actions. His remarks at the Border Security Expo highlight ongoing challenges and the necessity for cooperation between immigration agencies to address border concerns.

stories.headline: Citrus Squeeze: Fruit could find new life in niche operations
stories.summary: Amidst challenges in traditional citrus farming in Arizona, niche operations and fresh market opportunities offer potential paths for industry revitalization. Farmers like Mark Kuechel see hope in adapting orchard operations to meet modern demands, driven by historic family ties and a commitment to sustaining the legacy of citrus farming in the region.

stories.headline: Federal checks on voters sought
stories.summary: Local election officials in Arizona plan to request assistance from the U.S. Department of Homeland Security to conduct citizenship checks on over 48,000 voters. These checks, which could impact future elections, are not mandated by state or federal law. The initiative aims to verify voter eligibility, stirring debate and potential legal ramifications.

stories.headline: Charter captain seen in video arrested
stories.summary: Brock Horner, a charter captain, was arrested following a viral video showing him terrorizing and assaulting a fisherman. The incident led to police advancing charges against him. Investigations by several authorities, including the Coast Guard, continue.

stories.headline: UF rallies to become national champions
stories.summary: The University of Florida Gators celebrated a victory over Houston, winning the college basketball national championship. The Gators triumphed with a score of 65-63, marking an important achievement for the team and its players.

stories.headline: China accuses Trump of 'blackmail'
stories.summary: China has accused President Trump of blackmail over proposed tariff increases as tensions rise between the two countries. China vowed to fight if the U.S. insists on implementing these tariffs. White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt stated Trump's intention to protect American interests.

stories.headline: Unusually cool weather forecast
stories.summary: A significant cool front is spreading across the United States, bringing chilly, dry conditions to South Florida, considered unusual for this time of year. AccuWeather meteorologist John Feerick highlights that this could be the final significant cold front for the season, forecasting potential rain in some areas of Palm Beach County.

stories.headline: Moulin Rouge Workshop Shows Kids How They Can Can-Can
stories.summary: A workshop inspired by Moulin Rouge is teaching kids the art of the can-can dance, providing cultural and artistic engagement for young participants.

stories.headline: City Council Crackdown on Rogue Towing Companies
stories.summary: The City Council is considering new measures to empower police to regulate towing companies accused of exploiting drivers, aiming to address complaints about towing practices in Chicago.

stories.headline: Ex-Guantánamo Detainee Could Air Allegations of Torture by Former CPD Detective
stories.summary: A former Guantánamo detainee could present allegations of torture against a former Chicago Police Department detective, raising concerns about past interrogation practices.

stories.headline: Chicago Shoppers’ Market Jitters
stories.summary: Anxious consumers in Chicago are changing their buying habits and seeking deals as grocery prices rise amid tariff issues linked to Trump's policies. Some are even considering food banks to manage costs.

stories.headline: Westfield mall is a ghost of opulent first day
stories.summary: The Westfield San Francisco Centre, which opened in 2006 with much fanfare, now struggles with empty retail spaces following a series of store closures. Once a thriving shopping destination, it now symbolizes the challenges faced by urban malls in adapting to changing consumer habits and economic pressures.

stories.headline: Teen picking up activist mantle in red Kern County
stories.summary: In Bakersfield, a high school student named Hernandez is becoming a youth activist, organizing walkouts and protests against controversial local issues, including those supported by the Republican Party. This activism is notable given the conservative leaning of Kern County.

stories.headline: A new gold rush for Jackson Square
stories.summary: Jackson Square in San Francisco is witnessing a rise in real estate investments. As the rest of the city's commercial areas struggle, this historic district is attracting investors due to its preserved charm and architectural appeal. New businesses are signing leases, seeing the area as ripe for development and growth.

stories.headline: State bar to require diversion for DA
stories.summary: The State Bar of California plans to conclude its ethics complaints against San Francisco District Attorney Brooke Jenkins without formal disciplinary action. This move follows an investigation into minor misconduct allegations. The bar will recommend Jenkins join a diversion program aimed at educating and preventing future ethical violations.

stories.headline: Federal cuts endanger ‘critical’ safety programs for Alaska’s commercial fishermen
stories.summary: Proposed U.S. Department of Health and Human Services cuts to programs deemed 'critical' for Alaska’s commercial fishing safety have faced criticism. These programs help prevent accidents and fatalities in the fishing industry, essential for Alaska’s economy.
people: National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH)

stories.headline: Alaska House deadlocked on spending plan
stories.summary: The Alaska House remains at an impasse over budget approval due to disagreements on the Permanent Fund dividend size and education funding. The situation halts legislative progress as debates continue among lawmakers.

stories.headline: Supreme Court blocks order to reinstate fired federal workers
stories.summary: The Supreme Court blocked a lower court order requiring the Trump administration to rehire thousands of federal employees let go due to alleged rule violations. This move could significantly impact federal workforce reductions planned by the administration.

stories.headline: Experts say APD policy of not naming certain homicide victims has no basis in law
stories.summary: The Anchorage Police Department's policy of not identifying juvenile or domestic violence homicide victims is questioned as lacking a legal basis. The department stopped naming such victims in 2020 to protect families, but public outcry and legal experts now challenge this decision.

stories.headline: Why water fluoridation, long considered a public health success story, is under scrutiny
stories.summary: US Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. plans to review the use of fluoridation, traditionally endorsed for dental health. A task force will be set up to assess the policy following news of reduced mandates during the Trump administration and ongoing debates about its necessity.

stories.headline: US, Iran to discuss Tehran's nuclear program
stories.summary: The US and Iran are set for discussions over Tehran's nuclear program. Upcoming talks mark the first serious engagement between the two countries since the US exited the nuclear deal in 2018. Recent increased tensions and sanctions have spurred direct negotiations to manage potential escalation.

stories.headline: County residents trying to curb growth
stories.summary: Residents in unincorporated parts of Hamilton County are meeting with officials to draft plans that balance development between rural and urban areas. They seek to control rapid growth by adjusting living densities and commercial regulations while engaging with local government to manage infrastructure effectively.

stories.headline: Some leaders refuse to sign DEI order
stories.summary: Democratic-led states are contesting a Trump administration directive that threatens to cut federal funding over diversity, equity, and inclusion compliance. States like Minnesota and New York oppose signing off on such orders, reflecting widespread resistance to federal pressures on civil rights issues.

stories.headline: China Says Retaliatory Tariffs Coming
stories.summary: In response to President Trump's tariff threats, China announced it will impose countermeasures to protect its interests, escalating tensions in the ongoing trade dispute between the two nations.

stories.headline: Multifaith Leaders Decry State Probes
stories.summary: Muslim, Jewish, and Christian leaders held a news conference to denounce the numerous investigations affecting Muslim-centric areas, with the Council on American-Islamic Relations describing it as oppressive.

stories.headline: Luka's Lasting Legacy
stories.summary: Boys named Luka are scattered across North Texas, with families sharing stories about naming their sons after basketball star Luka Doncic. The trend highlights the Slovene player's influence and popularity.

stories.headline: Paxton Launches Bid for Senate
stories.summary: Attorney General Ken Paxton has announced his candidacy for Senate, set to challenge Republican incumbent John Cornyn in a potentially heated 2026 primary battle. This move could significantly alter the political landscape in Texas.

stories.headline: Kuna OK’s rezoning request for another large data center
stories.summary: Diode Ventures has obtained permission to rezone land in Kuna for a data center. The center is slated for a large area, reflecting a broader interest in Idaho for tech-related expansions. This development is part of Idaho's ongoing economic transformation.

stories.headline: Idaho Supreme Court rules against Bundy in Capitol case
stories.summary: Ammon Bundy's legal challenges continue as the Idaho Supreme Court rules against him in a case related to his 2020 actions at the Idaho Statehouse. Bundy, known for his activism, has been denied relief on convictions from events during the COVID-19 protests.

stories.headline: State lawmaker says 'nothing to disclose' in backing bill
stories.summary: Senator Codi Galloway has been backing a bill concerning homeless encampments, but faced questions about potential conflicts of interest due to her husband's business, Create Spaces. Galloway insists there is nothing to disclose, focusing on the importance of public safety.

stories.headline: Momentous hearings over evidence await Kohberger
stories.summary: Bryan Kohberger, accused of killing four University of Idaho students in November 2022, is returning to court for key evidentiary hearings. Since February, extensive legal filings have been made, and the hearing will determine if the evidence is sufficient to proceed with the capital murder trial set for summer 2025.

stories.headline: Polk County Homeowners See Average 10% Hike in Assessments
stories.summary: Homeowners in Polk County are experiencing a near 10% increase in property assessments. This rise is part of a trend, although the latest hike is lower than increases seen in previous years.

stories.headline: Iowa Republicans Start MAGA Nation
stories.summary: Iowa Republican BJ James McLaughlin, along with fellow conservatives, has launched the MAGA Nation Networks to support Donald Trump’s agenda. This new grassroots organization aims to sustain momentum among Trump's 'ruby red' supporters in the state.

stories.headline: Council Approves $986M Budget
stories.summary: The Des Moines City Council approved a $986 million budget for the upcoming fiscal year after some community members expressed concerns about potential cuts. The budget includes funding for sustainability offices and violence reduction programs, despite opposition faced from parts of the community.

stories.headline: Barriers still keep officers from getting help
stories.summary: Stigma continues to prevent Massachusetts police officers from seeking mental health care. This lack of support may have serious consequences on their well-being and effectiveness in the line of duty.

stories.headline: Grain of truth
stories.summary: Recent governmental decisions, including the IRS’s new agreements to help officials deport immigrants and adjust policies, reflect deeper tensions and have economic impacts. These moves have led to a plunge in business confidence following COVID-19.

stories.headline: At Harvard lab, fear that crucial fight against TB will be sidelined
stories.summary: Harvard University is facing potential setbacks in tuberculosis research due to other pressing projects taking priority. This could impact the University’s ability to lead in this critical public health area.

stories.headline: Countries ready to deal, says Trump
stories.summary: The Trump administration announced it is prepared to negotiate deals regarding tariffs with targeted countries. The next round of tariffs is set to start, with discussions involving the United States, Japan, South Korea, and others.

stories.headline: This time, they’re replaying for keeps
stories.summary: In Lincoln, Massachusetts, reenactors are celebrating the 250th anniversary of a historic battle. This event sees participants recreating the famous clash between British Redcoats and local minutemen, bringing history to life for spectators.

stories.headline: Embattled councilor says she’s resigning
stories.summary: Boston City Councilor Tania Fernandes Anderson has agreed to plead guilty to federal corruption charges and announced that she will resign. Her charges include allegedly arranging to receive a kickback and wire fraud. She has apologized to her constituents and supporters.
